title: Growth hacking will kill you | Prime Moving Notes
paragraphs: Mixing up cause and effect? Is not always as easy as we might assume to know what is what. Getting this wrong lead us to Dooms Day.﻿

During the last weeks I have spent time googling for answers on how to create viral effects. The effect everyone is dreaming of. I was curious on finding out how the global digital discussion about it was ongoing. In particular I was interested finding out what kind of facts and figures was floating around on the topic. Data, statistics etc on Growth Hacking.

Here is one link I found that obvously have became well spread: http://www.digitalinformationworld.com/2014/05/why-does-content-go-viral-social-media-infographic.html?m=1It tell that size is needed if you want to go viral. Statistics shown tell that out of the posts that go viral there is far more using 2000 words or more, than using less than 2000 words.
All this is backed up by data. Difficult to argue upon. Leading to conclusions like: write long posts, instead of short ones.
But is that a resonable conclusion? Try looking upon it this way instead:
Is it not tremendously tragic how quick we loose sight of the word relevance – just because someone can make statistics?
So skip the idea of caring about length of your posts. Skip the idea of letting statistics tell you what to do and how to do it. Write something relevant instead. And if lucky: get viral.
